title: The Masque of Mandragora
dialogue_triumphs: The Doctor's reaction to the court's action on being attacked: 'You're going to hold a dance?'
dialogue_disasters: In broad cockney: 'I ain't goin' in there, Giovanni.'
'They say there are places where the bat droppings are as high as a man.'
goofs: The Doctor only knows that Sarah's under Hieronymous's influence when she shows an undue amount of curiosity.
Hieronymous tells the Doctor that he's been told another follower of Mandragora will join him, but they never show up.
The time scheme is a bit of a mess: a clash of evening and broad daylight scenes, and an impossibly quickly arranged masque.
Nobody notices the Doctor and Sarah's out-of-period clothing.
When the Doctor mentions that he could have used Galileo's telescope 50 years later, he actually means 150, since Galileo didn't start using his until 1610.

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.current_status: Can mimic another's voice exactly, can ride horses, fences well, but hasn't met Leonardo Da Vinci. Carries a football rattle.

continuity_notes.current_status: The Doctor explains it as a gift he allows companions to share, implying conscious control.

continuity_notes.name: Mandragora Helix
continuity_notes.description: One of several helix intelligences, a spiralling energy mass that can manipulate energy into matter

continuity_notes.name: Sarah Jane Smith
continuity_notes.current_status: Traveling with the Doctor, height noted as 5'4" ('just')

roots: Roger Corman's The Masque of the Red Death

locations.name: San Martino, Italy
locations.current_status: Time period between 1470-1482 when Da Vinci was in Florence

untold_adventures: The Doctor learnt fencing from a Captain in Cleopatra's bodyguard
Between this story and 'City of Death' he meets Leonardo Da Vinci
additional_notes: The Cult of Demnos is a 3rd-century Roman cult, kept going until the 15th century. Fashion Victims: The Brotherhood leader's silver perm and Hieronymous's comedy beard.
bottom_line: One of the few metaphors in Doctor Who history (nasty alien energy mass = superstition and scientific ignorance) is blurred by the lack of actual scientific understanding that the story exhibits. Looks and sounds great, though.
